title: `st.image()` doesn't work with absolute local file-paths on Windows

labels.name: status:confirmed
labels.description: Bug has been confirmed by the Streamlit team

body: ### Checklist - [X] I have searched the [existing issues](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues) for similar issues. - [X] I added a very descriptive title to this issue. - [X] I have provided sufficient information below to help reproduce this issue. ### Summary On Windows, when passing an absolute local file-path to `st.image()`, Streamlit does not display the image. ### Reproducible Code Example ```Python # Note that this script assumes an image called "image.jpg" is located in # the same directory as this script from pathlib import Path import streamlit as st image_path = Path(__file__).with_name("image.jpg") st.image(str(image_path)) ``` ### Steps To Reproduce 1. Run a Streamlit application on Windows like the above code example 2. Open page on Streamlit ### Expected Behavior Image is displayed, e.g.: ![image](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/assets/7438501/e5b87e19-3555-4a5d-9b63-641fe6f9f004) ### Current Behavior Image is not displayed, only alt text is: ![image](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/assets/7438501/77fb5c00-a3f6-4daa-a4b4-830f220dd487) ### Is this a regression? - [ ] Yes, this used to work in a previous version. ### Debug info - Streamlit version: 1.26.0 - Python version: 3.10.12 - Operating System: Windows - Browser: Edge/Chrome/Firefox (all affected) ### Additional Information This is likely to be the same issue as #3698, which was closed for inactivity. I believe the root cause of this issue is in `streamlit.elements.image.image_to_url()`. Specifically, the function tries to detect whether the input string is a URL or path to a local file. It does this by passing the string to `urllib.parse.urlparse()` and checking the `scheme` attribute: ```py # Strings if isinstance(image, str): # If it's a url, return it directly. try: p = urlparse(image) if p.scheme: return image except UnicodeDecodeError: # If the string runs into a UnicodeDecodeError, we assume it is not a valid URL. pass ``` What this code fails to account for, is that on Windows, the "disk" part in an absolute path looks a bit like a "scheme" to the `urllib.parse.urlparse()` function: ```pycon >>> from urllib.parse import urlparse >>> urlparse("C:\\Path") ParseResult(scheme='c', netloc='', path='\\Path', params='', query='', fragment='') ``` So the function mistakenly assumes that the path is a URL, and embeds this directly into the local HTML of the page, like this: ```html ``` #### Workaround You can work around this issue by providing a relative path instead of an absolute path. For example, applying this workaround to the reproduceable code example above: ```py from pathlib import Path import streamlit as st image_path = Path(__file__).with_name("image.jpg").relative_to(Path.cwd()) st.image(str(image_path)) ```
